title: 108_s2511
content: The Act is titled the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions for the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Act titled "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004" defines key terms such as Secretary, study area, system, and town. It mandates a feasibility study by the Secretary to construct a water supply system for the Town of Chimayo in the Santa Cruz River Valley, including transmission lines, pump stations, and reservoirs. The Secretary is required to conduct a study for the Chimayo Water Supply System, considering various water supply options, reuse of water sources, alternative water supplies, and determining the total lifecycle costs of the system. The Secretary is mandated to conduct a study for the Chimayo Water Supply System, with a deadline of 3 years after enactment. The Federal share of the study cost is 75 percent, and coordination with relevant agencies is required. A report on the feasibility study must be submitted to Congress within a specified timeframe. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible entities in the study area, including activities such as hauling water, installing purification technology, drilling wells, and constructing pump stations and pipelines. The feasibility study results must be submitted within a specific timeframe. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance for activities such as installing pipelines, designing emergency systems, and other eligible activities determined by the Secretary. The Federal share of the cost for these activities shall be 75 percent. SEC. 104. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $2,000,000 for section 102 for fiscal years 2005-2008 and $3,000,000 for section 103 for fiscal years 2005-2010. Limitation: Funds under (a)(1) not for water infrastructure construction. The term "component" refers to a water delivery infrastructure development, while "facility" pertains to the Espanola water filtration facility. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Commissioner of Reclamation, is defined as the "Secretary." The Secretary is tasked with providing financial assistance to the city of Espanola, New Mexico, for the construction of the Espanola water filtration facility, which includes projects to divert and utilize imported water for future demands in the region. The curr_chunk discusses the components of a water delivery infrastructure development project for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos in New Mexico, including pump stations, filtration facilities, storage facilities, and transmission lines. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the project, which aims to use reclaimed water to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. The Federal share of the total cost of the facility and its components cannot exceed 25 percent, and funds provided by the Secretary cannot be used for operation or maintenance. Authorization of $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
